metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Paul Rouffart & Ors.

facts.text: A.C.E.C. Private India Limited carried on business in India and made profits during the calendar year 1947. Accounting year is calendar year ending December 31, 1948; relevant assessment year 1949-50.
Company did not declare any dividend at shareholders' meeting held on December 4, 1948.

On March 29, 1954, Income-tax Officer passed order under s.23A(1) deeming income divided amongst shareholders: Mr. Paul Rouffart Rs.1,09,859/-; Mr. Paul Victor Hermans Rs.1,00,189/-; Mr. Robert J. Sas Rs.1,09,859/-
Income-tax Officer issued notices under s.34 served on respondents on April 1, 1954.
Returns submitted, assessments completed for shareholders. Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, then Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.
Tribunal accepted plea that notices served beyond 4 years under s.34(1)(b), no jurisdiction.
Commissioner referred case to Bombay High Court under s.66(1): two questions on necessity of s.34 action and timeliness of notice.
High Court reframed second question and answered both affirmatively against Commissioner.
Appeals by special leave to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer must initiate action under s.34 to tax deemed income under s.23A(1).
Whether notice under s.34 served on April 1, 1954 was out of time.

petitioner_arguments.text: No limitation prescribed for order under s.23A; applying s.34(1)(b) period would make s.23A unworkable.
Under s.23A(1), 6-month period for dividends; accounting year 1949, assessment year 1950-51; notice within 4 years up to March 31, 1955.
Proviso 1 to s.34(3) applies; notice issued within 4 years under s.34(1)(b), assessment within 1 year of service valid.

respondent_arguments.text: Income-tax Officer had no jurisdiction as notices served beyond 4 years under s.34(1)(b).

court_reasoning.text: First issue no longer survives per Sardar Baldev Singh and CIT v. Navinchandra Mafatlal; assessment only under s.34.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.23A does not provide for assessment; requires s.34.

court_reasoning.text: s.23A(1) creates fictional dividend deemed distributed on date of general meeting (Dec 4, 1948); accounting year 1948, assessment year 1949-50.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deemed distribution date is general meeting, not end of 6 months.

court_reasoning.text: Notice under s.34(1)(b) must be served within 4 years from end of relevant assessment year (1949-50 ends March 31, 1953); April 1, 1954 out of time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Period under s.34(1)(a)/(b) from end of assessment year per First Additional ITO v. H.N.S. Iyengar.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s.34(3) not raisable as not covered by referred questions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question limited to service of notice under s.34(1)(b).

court_reasoning.text: s.23A not unworkable with s.34 time limit.

holdings.text: Assessment under s.23A requires s.34 notice; first question affirmed.
Notice served April 1, 1954 out of time under s.34(1)(b) for 1949-50 assessment year.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: s.23A does not make provision for assessment; only under s.34

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Navinchandra Mafatlal
precedents_cited.relevance: s.23A does not make provision for assessment; only under s.34

precedents_cited.case_name: Navinchandra Mafatlal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
First Additional Income-tax Officer, Mysore v. H.N.S. Iyengar
precedents_cited.relevance: Limitation period under s.34(1)(a)/(b) begins from end of assessment year

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.23A deems undistributed profits as dividends if less than 60% distributed by end of 6 months post general meeting; s.34 required for assessment with 4-year limit from end of assessment year

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; High Court correct that notice under s.34(1)(b) served on April 1, 1954 was out of time for 1949-50 assessment year relating to deemed dividends under s.23A(1).

key_quotes.text: s.23A(1) creates a fictional distribution of dividend which is deemed to be a receipt of dividend by the shareholder although in fact the shareholder does not receive it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains nature of deemed dividend under s.23A

key_quotes.text: the notice under s.34(1) is to be served within four years from the end of the assessment year.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: These appeals, therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
